Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Career Lifecycles of Enterprising Workers in R&D Intensive Industries

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Enterprising individuals build their careers, continuously making choices between staying at the start-ups they create, leaving to engage in serial entrepreneurship, or exiting into paid employment, either alone, as part of a small independent team, or as part of full company acquired by an established firm. These choices are shaped by experiences and constraints and, in turn, affect subsequent career choices and economic outcomes. Greater attention to human capital dynamics by tracing career histories of innovative personnel within and across firm boundaries may provide richer insights into economic dynamism. An examination of factors that impact enterprising workers' career choices can inform science and innovation policy to promote knowledge creation and diffusion.

The US Census Bureau Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD) Project provides near universal coverage that allows the construction of the career histories of enterprising individuals in R&D intensive industries across the 18 year time period from 1991-2008. The research focuses on the fates of these individuals after entrepreneurial activity by examining the paths that individuals take after exiting new ventures of different types and by examining the transferability of different entrepreneurial experiences outside of the entrepreneurial context. Family composition constrains geographical mobility which in turn shapes how enterprising individuals build their careers through mobility and entrepreneurship. Together the research explore important individual antecedents to, and consequences of, entrepreneurial activity.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the following questions: (1) What are the fates of enterprising individuals who engage in new venture creation?; and (2) How do mobility constraints create market frictions and facilitators that impact the subsequent career choices of enterprising individuals?

Motivating these research questions is the premise that the vibrancy of a knowledge economy is predicated on the enterprising action and agency of knowledge workers. Accordingly, by examining by factors that shape the antecedents and consequences of individuals? enterprising experiences we inform science and innovation policy that promotes knowledge creation and diffusion.  While much current policy is focused on shaping firm level outcomes, we demonstrated that deeper attention to human capital dynamics with a primacy on tracing career histories of innovative personnel within and across firm boundaries provides rich insights into understanding and promoting economic dynamism.

The research team focused on the core idea that as enterprising individuals build their careers, they continuously make choices between staying and growing the start-ups they create, leaving to engage in serial entrepreneurship, or exiting into paid employment?either alone, as part of a small independent team, or as part of full company acquired by an established firm. These choices are shaped by their experiences and constraints and, in turn, affect their subsequent career choices and outcomes.  This lens allowed the team to construct a framework for understanding the fates, frictions and facilitators of enterprising individuals? career choices. The research team explored the implications of this framework from multiple perspectives using data from the Longitudinal Establishment-Household Dynamics (LEHD) program of the US Census Bureau augmented with other data sources. These data allowed the team to examine (1) the paths that individuals take before joining and after exiting new ventures of different types; (2) the transferability of different classes of experiences within and outside of innovative contexts; and (3) how a variety of constraints shape how enterprising and innovative individuals build their careers through mobility and entrepreneurship.

 This approach supported multiple studies that cumulatively contribute to the scientific literature, to practitioners, and to policy makers.  The outcomes of the studies allowed the team to (1) document and explain how prior experiences shape how new hires match to entrepreneurs; (2) show the relative benefits of different aspects of entrepreneurial team members? prior experiences on new venture performance; (3) demonstrate the impact of within- and cross-industry experience on new venture entry, performance, and survival; (4) document the impact of patenting on inventor?s wages, mobility, and entrepreneurship; (5) inform workers? career decisions about how firm characteristics, geographical characteristics, and family characteristics may facilitate or create impediments to successful start-up entry and subsequent growth; and (6) help science and innovation policy makers in understanding how deeper attention to human capital dynamics with a primacy on tracing career histories of innovative personnel within and across firm boundaries may provide a richer measure of economic dynamism than a singular focus on new venture creation and jobs associated with start-ups.

 The outcomes of the award include multiple working papers, leading journal submissions, conference presentations and roundtable discussions, seminar presentations and the successful training and support of multiple doctoral students.


Last Modified: 01/18/2019
Modified by: Seth Carnahan

Motivating these research questions is the premise that the vibrancy of a knowledge economy is predicated on the enterprising action and agency of knowledge workers. Accordingly, by examining by factors that shape the antecedents and consequences of individuals? enterprising experiences we inform science and innovation policy that promotes knowledge creation and diffusion. While much current policy is focused on shaping firm level outcomes, we demonstrated that deeper attention to human capital dynamics with a primacy on tracing career histories of innovative personnel within and across firm boundaries provides rich insights into understanding and promoting economic dynamism. The research team focused on the core idea that as enterprising individuals build their careers, they continuously make choices between staying and growing the start-ups they create, leaving to engage in serial entrepreneurship, or exiting into paid employment?either alone, as part of a small independent team, or as part of full company acquired by an established firm.
